the nature of true dignity and real manii-
ness. That the most perfect dignity OF
character and manner is consistent with
these virtues, was eminently manifested in
Him who was beyond all others, ''meek
and lowly in heart" That $hirit which is
by some SO greatly admired, would, upon in

Do we need inducements to cultivate this
temper? Let us make the trial for one day;
let us be peaceable, meek, forbeal'ing, sub
missiye; determining not to be provoked by
provocaton; and remark, if that day will not
be more productive ofhappincss to ourselves
as we'll as to all around us, than another in
which rights have been maintained, privi-
leges asserted, insults returned, and wrongs
ever so successfully revenged. This, IN
deed, must be the case, because holiness and
happiness, our duty and our interest, are in
separately connected.


Let our young readers then, while they
wisely repress that inordinate attention to
external decoration which SO generally pre-
walls, be ambitious to win and wear this
choice array, these precious ornaments. Let
them "learn of Him who was meek and
lowly in heart, and they shall find peace in
their consciences and rest to their SOULS"

Perhaps there is no country in the world
where the women are more completely DO
mestic, than they are in our country; and
none where female influence is more gen
orally felt. This is the most happy. clrcum-
stance; and it affords a most powerful argu-
ment in favor of female education.


1t is trite ! know, but very important to
remark, that when ladies are distinguished
for domestic habits and virtues, their mu-
tual influence is very great


They mould the hearts, and to great
degree, from the understanding of the fu-
ture fathers and mothers in our country.
Now they who have in their hands so great
a part Of early education, certainly ought
to receive that cultivation of heart and mind
which would fit them for the discharge OF
the very important duties oftheir station
This is no easy work. 1t demands skiliand
Judgment as we'll as attention. surely prep
aration ought to be made for it, that 1T may
be done we'll. Look at the majority OF girls
of eighteen, in the country, and see what
are their qualifications for place at the
head of household.


But female influence IS felt not only in
domestic life; it reaches to every part o:
socity. Every where it ought to be intel
lectual as we'll as sensitive; intelligent as
we'll as affablc, good as we'll as pretty. NC
where indeed are they more pure and deli
cate than among ourselves; but II to those
graces of the female character were added
suitable mental improvement, the$ef on
the whole. community would be most happy
A higher spirit of literature woulds'pervade
our states; and young men would spend that
time in study, which they now waste in dis
sipation. A lofter tone or. moral feeling


would be awakened, and wegmight hope tt


witness the purity without the extravagan
/ ces of chivalry.
THE LADIES' FRIEND.
AMERICAN LADIES.

1t is astonishinghow little has been writ
ten or spoken upon that most exalted Of all
the sacrifices ever made by mere mortals,
which is recorded in the eleventh chapter
of JUDGES The divine historian has not e.
ven given us the name of the fair victim.
Jephthah, returning from the slaughter of
twenty cities, and the complete conquest of
the enemies of Israel, rashly vowed, that
whatsoever come forth of the doors of his
house to meet him, should surely be the
Lords, and should be sacrificed with fire !
His daughter, an only daughter! for she is
emphaticaly called "the daughter of Jeph-
thah, the Gileadite," indeed an only child,
gay in all the loyeiness of youth and beauty,
and animated to enthusiasm by the pros
pect of her brave fathers approaching tri-
umph, came out to meet him with timbrels
and with dances, unconcious of the awful
doom to which she was destined! When,
in all the agony of regret and sorrow. he an
nounced to her the vows which he deemed
irrevocable, how dignihed her composure,
how unparalleled her heroism She resort
ed to no sophistical evasions to avert the
blow that impended over her; scarcely con-
descended to express regret for her untme-
ly fate. My father, if thou hast opened thy
mouth unto the Lord, do to me according to
that which hath proceeded out OF tiny mouth
-forasmuch as the Lord hath taken venge-
ancc for thee of thine enemies. even OF the
children of Ammon. All she requested,
was that herself and the companions of her
intantie pleasures might be permitted to
wander for two months upon the lonely
mountains, to prepare herself for death
more glorious than that of the most cele-
brated hero of ancient or modern ages
Compared with this, how trif1ing the boast
ell sacrifice of Lhhigema, which indeed, from
the silence OF Homer, who could neither
have forgotten nor despised ahincident SO
suited to his taste. and SO capable OF en-
bellshi g his poem, we ought to regard as
altogether fabulous.


Sweet simplicity of the patriarchal ages,
ennobled by self-devotion more sublime than
that of Codorus or Curtins 1t is the busi-
ness Of soldier and king to die in the
field of battle, but what could poor rural
girl feel of martial enthusiasm. or expect of
future fame!
JEPHTHAH'S DAUGHTER.

Mercy on us who is that female so loud
upon our right! Of a surety, she must be
the original woman who hired the devil to
teach her how to outscold all her neighbors.


Bartholomew Fair.


MY tale is not so much about the log cab
in as its contents, though every one who had
travelled from Alesbury to Burling Ford,
must remember the three-cornered pine-log
hut at the foot ot the Red Ridge, rooted
with loose slabs, with a mud and straw CHM
ney, and a large hole cut out of one side for
the double purpose of door and window.
And if there was not such another Cabin IN
the country, neither was there just such an
other pair as the honest couple who inhab-
tied 1.-THE land on which it stood belong
ed to a distant proprietor. as such lands
were considered "free'', the present tenant,
Peter Keltzer, had put up the dwelling him
self, with such assistance as two quarts OF
whiskey commanded on the raising day, and
lived as one would readily imagine from his
manner of living, entirely unincnmbered
with ground rent.


Peter had scarcely troubled himself to cut
away the bushes that>grew by his door. He
minded neither the grubbing hoe nor the
pruning knife, his only implement of hus-
bandry, if may call it so, was rough bor-
ed rifle, which he kept in admirable order,
and with which he never failed to do excel
lent service, whenever necessity or whim
drove him to scour the forest, and climb the
rugged mountains, or trace up the winding
streams in pursuit of game--and, in truth,
necessity or whim kept the poor man pref
ty constantly on the scout, tor when their
venison was not out, Madame Keltzer's tenn
per always was, and the failure of the one
or the other was An equal misfortune for Pc
ter.


Dame Keltzer was thin, sharp visaged
lady, about five feet two; with black pierc.
ing eye, and but three teeth; the others, a:
Peter affirmed, having been utterly worn
out'of her mouth by the constant concus-
sions of her tongues, which also, were Mret
in number, if his word might pass for value
indeed he gravely asserted that it was ir
consequence Of these remarkable and coin
Gliding anomalies, that the Dame had COM
PEELED him after years fire to build three.
THE LOG CABIN,

We have read, with good deal Of inter-
est, Capt. Weddell's Narrative of Voyage
towards the South Pole. He succeeded in
reaching considerably higher latitude than
Capt. Cook, or any preceding navigator;
and when he put back, had before him a
clear sea, without land once in view, to OBJ
struct an onward course. Being however
on mercantile voyage, and in very small
and, for the purposes of discovery, unpro-
vided vessel, he was compelled to torego
the honor of penetrating further. The in
formation he has impaired will, we doubt
not, lead to some better organized undertake
ing for discovery in that region.-Capt.
Wedteil visited the Falkland Islands, the
inhabitants Of that place, and their quiet,
inohensive manners, he gives an interesting
account. We have made some extracts
from the work, which will we think, be
found interestng-among them the follow


ing story, which is new to us, in all its parts.


NJ r. american.


New Island is remarkable tor having been,
for two years, the solitary residence OF
Capt. j. Barnard, an American; whose ves-
sci was run away with in the year 1914, by
the crew of all English ship, which, ON her
passage flom Port Jackson, had been wreck
| ed on the south side of these islands. met
with Captain Barnard in 1914, at the place
| of his exile, and his conversation naturally
to that subject, which, being interesting 81
greedily devoured." A particular account of
| his residence on an uninhabited island.
would not fail of being considered almost as
wonderful as the celebrated fiction of Rob-
inson Crusoe, since there was great sinii
! larity in their situations. The principal ihi
cidents attendant upon this event were al
follows:-Capt. Barnard was at New Island
withAlis vessel in the performance of voyi
age for seal furs, and when on the south
j Side of the island, he met with the crew of
the wrecked English ship. Their. number


might be about 80, including several passed.
gers, some of whom were ladies. He kind
i ly took them to his vessel, and treated them


with all the hospitality which their destd-
tute situation required. Captain Barnard
was then at war, and this circumstance crc-
ated doubts as to the cerity of their friend
ly intentions to one another, though he had
i promised to land them on their passage
home at some port in the Brazils.


Owing TO the additional number of people,
hunting parties were frequently sent ont; to
procure supplies; and when the Captain,
with four of his people, we're on an excpr-
sion of this kind, the wrecked crew cut the
cable, and in defiance of the Americans Dho


were on BOARD, ran away with the ship to
Rio Janeiro; whence they proceeded tot N.
America.


! On Capt. Barnard's return to New-Island,
he was struck with astonishment at finding
his ship carried off. as he never suspected
any design of the kind. rOn reflection, how
ever. he soon guessed the cause. as it was
quite apparent. that the fear of being taken
to America, where they would become


prisoners of war. had been the motive to the
I commission of this action, which was bad


return for the asylum Capt. Barnard had
afforded the perpetrators of it. His conduct
towards them certainly did not justify their

much like it. At the end OF every evil and
improvident course there is corresponding
punishment; and they are comparatively
happy, who like Peter and Polly Keltzer,
are made wise by misfortune, while there is
yet time to profit by repentance.

"The great danger to virtuous man a.
Eses from the excess of his virtuous propen-
|ities. 1t is his duty to preserve with the
post religious care, just balance among all
|he natural sentiments and moral principles
y his character; and to watch with the ut
post vigilance the first symptom of any ten
|ency to excess. in any single principle or
passion. He must never forget the maxim


ancient wisdom, "omnes virtutes medic
fritate quadan esse moderatas.." If he a.
Pandon himself to the guidance of any sin


le principle. it matters not whether it be


zeal for the glory of God, or for the saliva
ion Of man. for the quiet of society, or for


he establishment of liberty; for Popery or
Calvanism; for Monarchy or Democracy; it
sure equally to drown the voice of reason,


b silence the feelings ofnature, to dishonor


lis own character, and, if he be armed with
power. to vex and scourge the human fam
&y.
THE MONITOR.
EXTRACT.

From tie Eurohean Magazine.


When we speak of simplicity. it were in
|,tice to the names of the unknown bard,

mes, the author of which has sided down

land them IN the bTaZllS.


Nothing in the way of supplies having
been left for poor Barnard and his four COM
panions, of which even the captors of his
ship ought have thought, he was forced to
consider how they were to subsist; and re-
collecting that he had planted a few potatoes,
they directed their attention to them, and in
the course of the second season, obtained
serviceable supply. They had dog which
now and then caught pig; and the eggs of
the albatross, which were stored at the prop
er season, with potatoes, formed substitute
for bread; and the skins Of the seals for
clothes. They built house OF stone, still
remaining on the island, which was strong
enough to withstand the storms of wiRter,
and they might have been comparatively
happy, but that they were cut off from their
relations and friends, without any immediate
prospect of being removed from the island.


To add to the misfortunes of Captain
Barnard in being separated from his wife
and children, his companions. over whom he
exercised no authority. but merely dictated
what he considered was for their mutual adj
vantage, became impatient even of this
mild controul, took an opportunity to steal
the boat, and he was left on the island alone.
After being thus entirely abandoned, he
spent the time in preparing clothes from
the skin of the seal, and in collecting food
tor winter. Once or twice day he used to
ascend hill, from which there was wide
prospect of the ocean, to see if any vessel
approached, but always retired disappoint-
ed and forlorn--no ship was to be observed.
The four sailors, in the meanwhile, having
experienced their own inability to provide
properly for themselves, returned to him afs
ter an absence Of some months.


He still found some difficulty in preserv-
ing peace among his companions; indeed,
one of them had planned his death, but for
tunately it was discovered in time to be pre-
vented. He placed this man alone with some
provisions, ON small island in Quaker har-
bour, and in the course of three weeks, so
great change was made on his mind, that
when Captain Barnard took him off, he was
worn down with reflection on his crimes,
and truly penitent.


They were now attentive to the advice Of
their commander, and the above mentioned
offender became truly religious and exem-
plary in his behaviour. In this way they
continued to live, occasionally visiting the
neghboring island in search of provisions,
till the end of two years when they were TAX =
en- off in the month of December, 1915, by
an English whaler, bound for the Pacific.
Captain Barnard informed me, that British
man of war had been sent expressly from
Rio Janeiro, to take them off, but by some
accident the vessel. though at the islands.
did not fall IN with them.


Captain Weddell thus describes the PEN
gums, which abound in great numbers in
South Georgia, an island east of Cape Horn.


No land quadrupeds are found here; birds
and amphibious animals are the only inhab-
tants. Of the bird tribe, the king penguin
is the most worthy of notice. The penguns
Cor. as they ought properly to be called, pir-
gums, the name being evidently derived
from the Latin word hinguedo. on account
of its fatness) are OF very gregarious ma
ture. They go in large hocks along the shore,
erect, and with waddling gait. When seen
through hazy atmosphere, they may not
be inaptly mistaken for a body of men--and
indeed, Sir John Marlborough has whimsic-
ally likened them to 'little children stand
ing up in white aprons" These he describes,
however, were avery diminutive species in
comparison with the king penguin, the bird
to which l refer.


In pride these birds are not surpassed even
by the peacock, to which in beanty of plu-
mage they are indeed very little inferior as.
may be seen in our principal museums.
During the time of moulting, they seem to
repel each other with disgust, on account Of
the ragged state of their coats; but as they
arrived at the maximum of splendour, they
re-assemble; and no one who has not COM
plcted his plumase, is allowed to enter the
community. They frequently looking down
their front and Sides in order to contemplate
the perfection .of their exterior brilliancy,
and to remove ANY speck which might sully
it, rs truly amazing to All observer.


About the BEGINNING of January they pair,
and lay their neggs During the 6ime of
Matching, the fnale' is remarkably assidu-
ous> so that wltsn tie hen has occasion to go
off I'd feed and Yist;the egg is transported


to hiR, which is a61k'by placing their toes
together, and folling'it from one to the other.


using their bessks q, place it properly. As


they have no nesk,itfs to be remarked, that


the esq is carrieT between the tail and legs,


where the feuals iin L, particular, has cavi-


ty for thepurposse; -, ~.


The hen keeps eharge,of her young near


" twelve laonth, during which time they
change and complete their plumagc; and


in teaching them to swim the mother has


frequently to use some artiticc; for when the


Young one refuses to take the water. she en-


tccs it to tlle side of a'rock, and cunningly


pushes it inj and this is repeated until it
takes the seq ofiss own accord. There are
three other. kinds, of. penguins. all of them
nearly OF the same size, but little more than
half the bipDess of that which have describ-

ner account, TO ODllRe MIN TO Tolerate anOln-
er trio in the chain of his misfortune. Pc
ter himself, though he possessed but COM
paratively small portion of his mates volu-
bility, was man of much courage, and
while in the frequent rencontress between
himself and madame Keltzer, to which he
was subjected, he was uniformly obliged to
beat the retreat, he turned his back with an
air of lortlly defiance, and his visage showed
evident signs of threatening retaliation.


Between parties so often belligerent, it
was hardly to be expected that every con-
test should end in smoke. Peter complained
to all his neighbors of his wife's reasonable
war upon his liberty, and accp>ed her with
design of reducing him to downright slave
ry; while she was not less prompt in charg-
ing him with an idle rambling disposition,
an entire neglect of all home AFFAIRS, and e.
ven with being guilty of amours with Some
of her good neighbours wives-whom he had
occasionally furnished with saddle OF ven.
ison or string of squirrels. AS the danes
suspicious seemed founded on this, the last
charge was probably untrue, but the others
were doubtless substantial, and incontroyert-
ible on either side.


No one who has seen any thing of the


world, need be told what kind OF advice the
friends Of our honest couple gave them on
these occasions, or that its tendency was not


in the smallest degree of a conciatory kind;


instead of growing better, things grew evil
IDENTIFY worse, and from oft repeated threats
on both Sides plans OF execution were re-


solved in the minds of both Peter and his


wife. The dame, in one particular, acquit-
ted herself with honor; she improved the
humble dwelling nightly in the course of
few years, and instead of a ground floor
,F ,rIp all, h,I
kind of trap door cut in the middle, di-
rectly under which she commenced hollow
ing out something like cellar, and made
such progress during one of Peters long
rambles that on his return, he began to sus


pcct the object oe SO much secrecy and des-
patch had some reference to himself. He
seriously believed Dame keltzer designed
preparing dungeon in which to immure
him. soul and body, and thereby execute
long standing threat that she would break
his rambling. In the confidence of his
strength, he determined to assist her, and
on the slightest symptom of the outbreak
ing of the conspiracy, to turn the punish


ment upon her.


We have now the worthy couple. each, in
the others absence, alternately embracing
the opportunity of following out deep cav


ern under the floor of the log cabin; and it
was persisted in, until it was actually, as
| found by measurement, nine feet deep. A
ladder was now tburst into it, and the dame
made use of it as temporary cellar, using


great precdut,on, however, never to enter it


while Peter was about home, and at the


same time seizng occasional opportunities of
! persuading him to SO down himself, under


one prctencc or another, for all of which she


found him too wisely cautious. At length


wearied with hope deferred, and Peter be.


coming in no wise reformed from his old in


veterate habits, on his return to the cabin


one dull damp evening. she took care to


have the door opened and the ladder drawn


up in readiness. The moment he set his


foot upon the threshold, she seized his arm,


and made a desperate attempt to accomplish


by force what she slespaired ever being a.
bic to do by stratagcm. A doubtful strug-


gle ensued and Peter partly disengaging him
self, so that as he fell, he seized and drag
ged the good woman after him, and she


catching at the door to stay herself, prccip-


itated it down over them both. The fan


did no injury. The dame in tenderness Tor


her husband, had deposited a quantity OF


fax which she had taken to spin, so that il


received them both, and when they fairly


recovered themselves on their feet, they
found neither had sustained damage, alft
both were fairly vanquished.


, At first they took separate corners of ths
cell, avowing themselves quite conten.ce
and comfortable. Then the dame began {
: commentary Of Peters evil life, which last
. ed untifnoon next days though poon broueh
small change from flight to them. Hunger
began its work; nothing to eat or drink wa
to be had, The business of mutual punish
ment went on apace, and long time. wa
5 borne with unacknowtedging obstinacy-h
, nally, however, neither could stand it longe
: "a truce was agreed upon-mutual ac
+ knowledgements passed; and at last the par
ties, thoroughly reconciled, agreed to assis
S each other out of this dreary confinement
This was no easy task, and had they no


abandoned all their jralousies and ill-will
t and abored in the closest concert, it woult
G never have been accomplished. Finally, b.
e gathering considerable pile of gravel be
: low, Peter took his wife upon his shoulder
: and she succeed from thence in climbing OH
:, The ladder was then put down and Pete
: himself obtained deliverance. What al
n the arguments in the world could never hav
e effected, this single incident did effect
6 thorough reform; and whenever afterwards
!, Peter was about doing amss, or dame kelt
: zer's voice exceeded common key, the re
r collection of the nine foot cellar, and thre
! days and nights passed therein, set all mat
e ters right.
JANUARY 4, 1927

lught to set so high value?-A meek and
(uiet spirit. o, what different world ours

Yecome fashionable but alas how rarely

Prong, insult, ingratitude. The peace OF

Fss by some petty contention. And here


simple means which would heal every
reach, calm every storm. allay every irrita-
on' There isa certain temper called shirit in

SEQ to meekuess and quietness. The We


terms, indeed. would probably excite in

the nature of true dignity and real manii-
ness. That the most perfect dignity OF
character and manner is consistent with
these virtues, was eminently manifested in
Him who was beyond all others, ''meek
and lowly in heart" That $hirit which is
by some SO greatly admired, would, upon in
vestigation, be found to be made up of the
most mean and pitifu qualities, and topro-
coed from contemplate species of vanity.


Do we need inducements to cultivate this
temper? Let us make the trial for one day;
let us be peaceable, meek, forbeal'ing, sub
missiye; determining not to be provoked by
provocaton; and remark, if that day will not
be more productive ofhappincss to ourselves
as we'll as to all around us, than another in
which rights have been maintained, privi-
leges asserted, insults returned, and wrongs
ever so successfully revenged. This, IN
deed, must be the case, because holiness and
happiness, our duty and our interest, are in
separately connected.


Let our young readers then, while they
wisely repress that inordinate attention to
external decoration which SO generally pre-
walls, be ambitious to win and wear this
choice array, these precious ornaments. Let
them "learn of Him who was meek and
lowly in heart, and they shall find peace in
their consciences and rest to their SOULS"

full articles.headline:
THE LADIES' FRIEND.

AMERICAN LADIES.
full articles.article:
Perhaps there is no country in the world
where the women are more completely DO
mestic, than they are in our country; and
none where female influence is more gen
orally felt. This is the most happy. clrcum-
stance; and it affords a most powerful argu-
ment in favor of female education.


1t is trite ! know, but very important to
remark, that when ladies are distinguished
for domestic habits and virtues, their mu-
tual influence is very great


They mould the hearts, and to great
degree, from the understanding of the fu-
ture fathers and mothers in our country.
Now they who have in their hands so great
a part Of early education, certainly ought
to receive that cultivation of heart and mind
which would fit them for the discharge OF
the very important duties oftheir station
This is no easy work. 1t demands skiliand
Judgment as we'll as attention. surely prep
aration ought to be made for it, that 1T may
be done we'll. Look at the majority OF girls
of eighteen, in the country, and see what
are their qualifications for place at the
head of household.


But female influence IS felt not only in
domestic life; it reaches to every part o:
socity. Every where it ought to be intel
lectual as we'll as sensitive; intelligent as
we'll as affablc, good as we'll as pretty. NC
where indeed are they more pure and deli
cate than among ourselves; but II to those
graces of the female character were added
suitable mental improvement, the$ef on
the whole. community would be most happy
A higher spirit of literature woulds'pervade
our states; and young men would spend that
time in study, which they now waste in dis
sipation. A lofter tone or. moral feeling


would be awakened, and wegmight hope tt


witness the purity without the extravagan
/ ces of chivalry.

full articles.headline: JEPHTHAH'S DAUGHTER.
full articles.article:
1t is astonishinghow little has been writ
ten or spoken upon that most exalted Of all
the sacrifices ever made by mere mortals,
which is recorded in the eleventh chapter
of JUDGES The divine historian has not e.
ven given us the name of the fair victim.
Jephthah, returning from the slaughter of
twenty cities, and the complete conquest of
the enemies of Israel, rashly vowed, that
whatsoever come forth of the doors of his
house to meet him, should surely be the
Lords, and should be sacrificed with fire !
His daughter, an only daughter! for she is
emphaticaly called "the daughter of Jeph-
thah, the Gileadite," indeed an only child,
gay in all the loyeiness of youth and beauty,
and animated to enthusiasm by the pros
pect of her brave fathers approaching tri-
umph, came out to meet him with timbrels
and with dances, unconcious of the awful
doom to which she was destined! When,
in all the agony of regret and sorrow. he an
nounced to her the vows which he deemed
irrevocable, how dignihed her composure,
how unparalleled her heroism She resort
ed to no sophistical evasions to avert the
blow that impended over her; scarcely con-
descended to express regret for her untme-
ly fate. My father, if thou hast opened thy
mouth unto the Lord, do to me according to
that which hath proceeded out OF tiny mouth
-forasmuch as the Lord hath taken venge-
ancc for thee of thine enemies. even OF the
children of Ammon. All she requested,
was that herself and the companions of her
intantie pleasures might be permitted to
wander for two months upon the lonely
mountains, to prepare herself for death
more glorious than that of the most cele-
brated hero of ancient or modern ages
Compared with this, how trif1ing the boast
ell sacrifice of Lhhigema, which indeed, from
the silence OF Homer, who could neither
have forgotten nor despised ahincident SO
suited to his taste. and SO capable OF en-
bellshi g his poem, we ought to regard as
altogether fabulous.


Sweet simplicity of the patriarchal ages,
ennobled by self-devotion more sublime than
that of Codorus or Curtins 1t is the busi-
ness Of soldier and king to die in the
field of battle, but what could poor rural
girl feel of martial enthusiasm. or expect of
future fame!

full articles.headline: THE LOG CABIN,
full articles.article:
Mercy on us who is that female so loud
upon our right! Of a surety, she must be
the original woman who hired the devil to
teach her how to outscold all her neighbors.


Bartholomew Fair.


MY tale is not so much about the log cab
in as its contents, though every one who had
travelled from Alesbury to Burling Ford,
must remember the three-cornered pine-log
hut at the foot ot the Red Ridge, rooted
with loose slabs, with a mud and straw CHM
ney, and a large hole cut out of one side for
the double purpose of door and window.
And if there was not such another Cabin IN
the country, neither was there just such an
other pair as the honest couple who inhab-
tied 1.-THE land on which it stood belong
ed to a distant proprietor. as such lands
were considered "free'', the present tenant,
Peter Keltzer, had put up the dwelling him
self, with such assistance as two quarts OF
whiskey commanded on the raising day, and
lived as one would readily imagine from his
manner of living, entirely unincnmbered
with ground rent.


Peter had scarcely troubled himself to cut
away the bushes that>grew by his door. He
minded neither the grubbing hoe nor the
pruning knife, his only implement of hus-
bandry, if may call it so, was rough bor-
ed rifle, which he kept in admirable order,
and with which he never failed to do excel
lent service, whenever necessity or whim
drove him to scour the forest, and climb the
rugged mountains, or trace up the winding
streams in pursuit of game--and, in truth,
necessity or whim kept the poor man pref
ty constantly on the scout, tor when their
venison was not out, Madame Keltzer's tenn
per always was, and the failure of the one
or the other was An equal misfortune for Pc
ter.


Dame Keltzer was thin, sharp visaged
lady, about five feet two; with black pierc.
ing eye, and but three teeth; the others, a:
Peter affirmed, having been utterly worn
out'of her mouth by the constant concus-
sions of her tongues, which also, were Mret
in number, if his word might pass for value
indeed he gravely asserted that it was ir
consequence Of these remarkable and coin
Gliding anomalies, that the Dame had COM
PEELED him after years fire to build three.

We have read, with good deal Of inter-
est, Capt. Weddell's Narrative of Voyage
towards the South Pole. He succeeded in
reaching considerably higher latitude than
Capt. Cook, or any preceding navigator;
and when he put back, had before him a
clear sea, without land once in view, to OBJ
struct an onward course. Being however
on mercantile voyage, and in very small
and, for the purposes of discovery, unpro-
vided vessel, he was compelled to torego
the honor of penetrating further. The in
formation he has impaired will, we doubt
not, lead to some better organized undertake
ing for discovery in that region.-Capt.
Wedteil visited the Falkland Islands, the
inhabitants Of that place, and their quiet,
inohensive manners, he gives an interesting
account. We have made some extracts
from the work, which will we think, be
found interestng-among them the follow


ing story, which is new to us, in all its parts.


NJ r. american.


New Island is remarkable tor having been,
for two years, the solitary residence OF
Capt. j. Barnard, an American; whose ves-
sci was run away with in the year 1914, by
the crew of all English ship, which, ON her
passage flom Port Jackson, had been wreck
| ed on the south side of these islands. met
with Captain Barnard in 1914, at the place
| of his exile, and his conversation naturally
to that subject, which, being interesting 81
greedily devoured." A particular account of
| his residence on an uninhabited island.
would not fail of being considered almost as
wonderful as the celebrated fiction of Rob-
inson Crusoe, since there was great sinii
! larity in their situations. The principal ihi
cidents attendant upon this event were al
follows:-Capt. Barnard was at New Island
withAlis vessel in the performance of voyi
age for seal furs, and when on the south
j Side of the island, he met with the crew of
the wrecked English ship. Their. number


might be about 80, including several passed.
gers, some of whom were ladies. He kind
i ly took them to his vessel, and treated them


with all the hospitality which their destd-
tute situation required. Captain Barnard
was then at war, and this circumstance crc-
ated doubts as to the cerity of their friend
ly intentions to one another, though he had
i promised to land them on their passage
home at some port in the Brazils.


Owing TO the additional number of people,
hunting parties were frequently sent ont; to
procure supplies; and when the Captain,
with four of his people, we're on an excpr-
sion of this kind, the wrecked crew cut the
cable, and in defiance of the Americans Dho


were on BOARD, ran away with the ship to
Rio Janeiro; whence they proceeded tot N.
America.


! On Capt. Barnard's return to New-Island,
he was struck with astonishment at finding
his ship carried off. as he never suspected
any design of the kind. rOn reflection, how
ever. he soon guessed the cause. as it was
quite apparent. that the fear of being taken
to America, where they would become


prisoners of war. had been the motive to the
I commission of this action, which was bad


return for the asylum Capt. Barnard had
afforded the perpetrators of it. His conduct
towards them certainly did not justify their

full articles.headline: TIE ORPHAN BOY.
full articles.article:
has! am an Orphan Boy,
With nought on earth to cheer my heart
|o fathers love, nor mothers joy,
Nor kin nor kind to take my part.
N lodging is the cold, cold ground.
T eat the bread of charity:
Ind when the kiss of love goes round,
There is no kiss, alas, fos me.
let once had father dear,
A mother, too, wont to prize:
With ready hand to wipe the tear,
| If chanc'd the transient tear to rise.
klt cause of tears was rarely found,
! For all my heart was youthful giec;
Ind when the kiss of love went round,
+ How sweet kiss there was tor me!
Ut, all! there came a war, they say;
What is warl-I cannot tell;-
he drums and flies did sweetly play,
| And loudly rang our village bell.
= truth, it was pretty sound
| thought; nor could thence foresee,
| hat when the kiss of love went round,
There soon would be no kiss for me.


scarlet coat my father took,
| And sword as bright as bright could bci
Ind feathers, that SO gaily look,
All in shining cap had he.
lhenhow my little heart did bound,
Alas, thought it fine to see;
bor dreamt that when the kiss went round,
There soon would be o.kiss for me.
II length the bell again didring--
There was victory. they said;
twas what my father SAID he'd bring,
But, ah! it brought my fatherd dead!
" mother shriek'd, her heart was woe,
| She clasp'd me to her trembling knee
! God, that you may never know,


How wild u kiss she gaveto me!


ut once again,--but once again.,


These lips mothers kisses felt; q


hat once again,-that once again,


Thetale a heart of stone would melt. Is


Twas when upon her death bed laid,
| 70 God! o God! that sight to see,)


by child, my child" she fecbly said,


And gave parting kiss to me.


% now I am an Orphan Boy,


With noughtsbelow my heart to cheer;


No mothers love, no fathers joy,
Nor kin nor kind to wipe the tear. 4.


Ny lodgingis is the cold, cold ground,


eat the bread of charity!


Ind whensthe kiss of love goes-round,a.


There is, alas, no kiss for me!

much like it. At the end OF every evil and
improvident course there is corresponding
punishment; and they are comparatively
happy, who like Peter and Polly Keltzer,
are made wise by misfortune, while there is
yet time to profit by repentance.

full articles.headline:
THE MONITOR.

EXTRACT.
full articles.article:
"The great danger to virtuous man a.
Eses from the excess of his virtuous propen-
|ities. 1t is his duty to preserve with the
post religious care, just balance among all
|he natural sentiments and moral principles
y his character; and to watch with the ut
post vigilance the first symptom of any ten
|ency to excess. in any single principle or
passion. He must never forget the maxim


ancient wisdom, "omnes virtutes medic
fritate quadan esse moderatas.." If he a.
Pandon himself to the guidance of any sin


le principle. it matters not whether it be


zeal for the glory of God, or for the saliva
ion Of man. for the quiet of society, or for


he establishment of liberty; for Popery or
Calvanism; for Monarchy or Democracy; it
sure equally to drown the voice of reason,


b silence the feelings ofnature, to dishonor


lis own character, and, if he be armed with
power. to vex and scourge the human fam
&y.

full articles.headline: tPG)-HH'tRYa
full articles.article:
From tie Eurohean Magazine.


When we speak of simplicity. it were in
|,tice to the names of the unknown bard,
n to introduce % notice, piece of former
mes, the author of which has sided down
|c current of oblivion, but which it will be
merit in any publication'to be the medium
frestoring.

land them IN the bTaZllS.


Nothing in the way of supplies having
been left for poor Barnard and his four COM
panions, of which even the captors of his
ship ought have thought, he was forced to
consider how they were to subsist; and re-
collecting that he had planted a few potatoes,
they directed their attention to them, and in
the course of the second season, obtained
serviceable supply. They had dog which
now and then caught pig; and the eggs of
the albatross, which were stored at the prop
er season, with potatoes, formed substitute
for bread; and the skins Of the seals for
clothes. They built house OF stone, still
remaining on the island, which was strong
enough to withstand the storms of wiRter,
and they might have been comparatively
happy, but that they were cut off from their
relations and friends, without any immediate
prospect of being removed from the island.


To add to the misfortunes of Captain
Barnard in being separated from his wife
and children, his companions. over whom he
exercised no authority. but merely dictated
what he considered was for their mutual adj
vantage, became impatient even of this
mild controul, took an opportunity to steal
the boat, and he was left on the island alone.
After being thus entirely abandoned, he
spent the time in preparing clothes from
the skin of the seal, and in collecting food
tor winter. Once or twice day he used to
ascend hill, from which there was wide
prospect of the ocean, to see if any vessel
approached, but always retired disappoint-
ed and forlorn--no ship was to be observed.
The four sailors, in the meanwhile, having
experienced their own inability to provide
properly for themselves, returned to him afs
ter an absence Of some months.


He still found some difficulty in preserv-
ing peace among his companions; indeed,
one of them had planned his death, but for
tunately it was discovered in time to be pre-
vented. He placed this man alone with some
provisions, ON small island in Quaker har-
bour, and in the course of three weeks, so
great change was made on his mind, that
when Captain Barnard took him off, he was
worn down with reflection on his crimes,
and truly penitent.


They were now attentive to the advice Of
their commander, and the above mentioned
offender became truly religious and exem-
plary in his behaviour. In this way they
continued to live, occasionally visiting the
neghboring island in search of provisions,
till the end of two years when they were TAX =
en- off in the month of December, 1915, by
an English whaler, bound for the Pacific.
Captain Barnard informed me, that British
man of war had been sent expressly from
Rio Janeiro, to take them off, but by some
accident the vessel. though at the islands.
did not fall IN with them.


Captain Weddell thus describes the PEN
gums, which abound in great numbers in
South Georgia, an island east of Cape Horn.


No land quadrupeds are found here; birds
and amphibious animals are the only inhab-
tants. Of the bird tribe, the king penguin
is the most worthy of notice. The penguns
Cor. as they ought properly to be called, pir-
gums, the name being evidently derived
from the Latin word hinguedo. on account
of its fatness) are OF very gregarious ma
ture. They go in large hocks along the shore,
erect, and with waddling gait. When seen
through hazy atmosphere, they may not
be inaptly mistaken for a body of men--and
indeed, Sir John Marlborough has whimsic-
ally likened them to 'little children stand
ing up in white aprons" These he describes,
however, were avery diminutive species in
comparison with the king penguin, the bird
to which l refer.


In pride these birds are not surpassed even
by the peacock, to which in beanty of plu-
mage they are indeed very little inferior as.
may be seen in our principal museums.
During the time of moulting, they seem to
repel each other with disgust, on account Of
the ragged state of their coats; but as they
arrived at the maximum of splendour, they
re-assemble; and no one who has not COM
plcted his plumase, is allowed to enter the
community. They frequently looking down
their front and Sides in order to contemplate
the perfection .of their exterior brilliancy,
and to remove ANY speck which might sully
it, rs truly amazing to All observer.


About the BEGINNING of January they pair,
and lay their neggs During the 6ime of
Matching, the fnale' is remarkably assidu-
ous> so that wltsn tie hen has occasion to go
off I'd feed and Yist;the egg is transported


to hiR, which is a61k'by placing their toes
together, and folling'it from one to the other.


using their bessks q, place it properly. As


they have no nesk,itfs to be remarked, that


the esq is carrieT between the tail and legs,


where the feuals iin L, particular, has cavi-


ty for thepurposse; -, ~.


The hen keeps eharge,of her young near


" twelve laonth, during which time they
change and complete their plumagc; and


in teaching them to swim the mother has


frequently to use some artiticc; for when the


Young one refuses to take the water. she en-


tccs it to tlle side of a'rock, and cunningly


pushes it inj and this is repeated until it
takes the seq ofiss own accord. There are
three other. kinds, of. penguins. all of them
nearly OF the same size, but little more than
half the bipDess of that which have describ-

full articles.headline: JANUARY 4, 1927
full articles.article:
ner account, TO ODllRe MIN TO Tolerate anOln-
er trio in the chain of his misfortune. Pc
ter himself, though he possessed but COM
paratively small portion of his mates volu-
bility, was man of much courage, and
while in the frequent rencontress between
himself and madame Keltzer, to which he
was subjected, he was uniformly obliged to
beat the retreat, he turned his back with an
air of lortlly defiance, and his visage showed
evident signs of threatening retaliation.


Between parties so often belligerent, it
was hardly to be expected that every con-
test should end in smoke. Peter complained
to all his neighbors of his wife's reasonable
war upon his liberty, and accp>ed her with
design of reducing him to downright slave
ry; while she was not less prompt in charg-
ing him with an idle rambling disposition,
an entire neglect of all home AFFAIRS, and e.
ven with being guilty of amours with Some
of her good neighbours wives-whom he had
occasionally furnished with saddle OF ven.
ison or string of squirrels. AS the danes
suspicious seemed founded on this, the last
charge was probably untrue, but the others
were doubtless substantial, and incontroyert-
ible on either side.


No one who has seen any thing of the


world, need be told what kind OF advice the
friends Of our honest couple gave them on
these occasions, or that its tendency was not


in the smallest degree of a conciatory kind;


instead of growing better, things grew evil
IDENTIFY worse, and from oft repeated threats
on both Sides plans OF execution were re-


solved in the minds of both Peter and his


wife. The dame, in one particular, acquit-
ted herself with honor; she improved the
humble dwelling nightly in the course of
few years, and instead of a ground floor
,F ,rIp all, h,I
kind of trap door cut in the middle, di-
rectly under which she commenced hollow
ing out something like cellar, and made
such progress during one of Peters long
rambles that on his return, he began to sus


pcct the object oe SO much secrecy and des-
patch had some reference to himself. He
seriously believed Dame keltzer designed
preparing dungeon in which to immure
him. soul and body, and thereby execute
long standing threat that she would break
his rambling. In the confidence of his
strength, he determined to assist her, and
on the slightest symptom of the outbreak
ing of the conspiracy, to turn the punish


ment upon her.


We have now the worthy couple. each, in
the others absence, alternately embracing
the opportunity of following out deep cav


ern under the floor of the log cabin; and it
was persisted in, until it was actually, as
| found by measurement, nine feet deep. A
ladder was now tburst into it, and the dame
made use of it as temporary cellar, using


great precdut,on, however, never to enter it


while Peter was about home, and at the


same time seizng occasional opportunities of
! persuading him to SO down himself, under


one prctencc or another, for all of which she


found him too wisely cautious. At length


wearied with hope deferred, and Peter be.


coming in no wise reformed from his old in


veterate habits, on his return to the cabin


one dull damp evening. she took care to


have the door opened and the ladder drawn


up in readiness. The moment he set his


foot upon the threshold, she seized his arm,


and made a desperate attempt to accomplish


by force what she slespaired ever being a.
bic to do by stratagcm. A doubtful strug-


gle ensued and Peter partly disengaging him
self, so that as he fell, he seized and drag
ged the good woman after him, and she


catching at the door to stay herself, prccip-


itated it down over them both. The fan


did no injury. The dame in tenderness Tor


her husband, had deposited a quantity OF


fax which she had taken to spin, so that il


received them both, and when they fairly


recovered themselves on their feet, they
found neither had sustained damage, alft
both were fairly vanquished.


, At first they took separate corners of ths
cell, avowing themselves quite conten.ce
and comfortable. Then the dame began {
: commentary Of Peters evil life, which last
. ed untifnoon next days though poon broueh
small change from flight to them. Hunger
began its work; nothing to eat or drink wa
to be had, The business of mutual punish
ment went on apace, and long time. wa
5 borne with unacknowtedging obstinacy-h
, nally, however, neither could stand it longe
: "a truce was agreed upon-mutual ac
+ knowledgements passed; and at last the par
ties, thoroughly reconciled, agreed to assis
S each other out of this dreary confinement
This was no easy task, and had they no


abandoned all their jralousies and ill-will
t and abored in the closest concert, it woult
G never have been accomplished. Finally, b.
e gathering considerable pile of gravel be
: low, Peter took his wife upon his shoulder
: and she succeed from thence in climbing OH
:, The ladder was then put down and Pete
: himself obtained deliverance. What al
n the arguments in the world could never hav
e effected, this single incident did effect
6 thorough reform; and whenever afterwards
!, Peter was about doing amss, or dame kelt
: zer's voice exceeded common key, the re
r collection of the nine foot cellar, and thre
! days and nights passed therein, set all mat
e ters right.

And what is this ornament on which we
lught to set so high value?-A meek and
(uiet spirit. o, what different world ours
Fould be. if this heavenly jewellery were to
Yecome fashionable but alas how rarely
70 We see it worn, we hear much outcry OF
Prong, insult, ingratitude. The peace OF
'sery private circle is interrupted, more or
Fss by some petty contention. And here


simple means which would heal every
reach, calm every storm. allay every irrita-
on' There isa certain temper called shirit in
0me young people, which is altogether op-


SEQ to meekuess and quietness. The We


terms, indeed. would probably excite in


s% . smile of contempt. But this would


Drove them 20 be unacQua ipteu wi
